children.value: é um framework para construção de sistemas distribuídos orientados a objetos
é um padrão aberto e extensível definido pela
clientes e servidores estão em diferentes máquinas
programas clientes enviam mensagens para servidores remotos como se este estivesse locais (
códigos de cliente e servidor portáveis  entre implementações CORBA
uma arquitetura mínima requer algumas dezenas de kB (segundo
encontrar uma implementação para uma requisição
possuem referências para objetos e invocam operações nestes objetos
conhecem apenas a interface dos objetos do servidor
não conhecem a implementação dos objetos nem os adaptadores utilizados por estas implementações
invocam interfaces definidas por uma IDL
provê interfaces independente de linguagem e sistema operacional
é puramente declarativa (não provê detalhes de implementação)
especificações podem ser escritas e invocadas em qualquer linguagem
- do cliente para o servidor e de volta para o cliente
CORBA define dois tipos de exceções:
: exceções definidas pelo usuário através da IDL
Implicitamente, todas as operações definidas na IDL podem lançar qualquer uma das exceções padrão do sistema CORBA
Nenhuma referência para exceções padrão devem aparecer na especificação da IDL
lançar uma exceção definida pelo usuário você deve:
primeiro definir a estrutura da exceção
uma exceção da IDL pode conter membros
The OMG CORBA specification defines the following exceptions:
- if a request does not contain a correct context this exception is raised.
- this exception indicates that operations has been invoked operations in the wrong order, which would cause, for example, a dead-lock.
- raised if the target object exists, but that the invoked operation is not supported.
- is thrown if, for example, a parameter is out of range or otherwise considered illegal.
- if illegal type code is passed, for example, encapsulated in an any data type the 'BAD_TYPECODE' exception will be raised.
- raised whenever an object cannot support the required quality of service.
- raised if two ORB's cannot communicate due to different representation of, for example, char and/or wchar.
- raised if an ORB is unable to setup communication or it is lost while an operation is in progress.
- raised if an ORB cannot convert data received to the native representation. See also the 'CODESET_INCOMPATIBLE' exception.
- the ORB failed to free dynamic memory and failed.
- an implementation limit was exceeded in the ORB at run time. A object factory may, for example, limit the number of object clients are allowed to create.
- an internal failure occurred in an ORB, which is unrecognized. You may consider contacting the ORB providers support.
- the ORB was not able to reach the interface repository, or some other failure relating to the interface repository is detected.
- the ORB initialization failed due to, for example, network or configuration error.
- is raised if the request carried an invalid transaction context.
- an invalid flag was passed to an operation, which caused, for example, a connection to be closed.
- this exception indicates that an IDL identifier is incorrect.
- this exception is raised if an objet reference is malformed or a nil reference (see also corba:create_nil_objref/0).
- the invocation cannot be made due to an incompatibility between policy overrides that apply to the particular invocation.
- this exception may be raised by the client- or server-side when either ORB is unable to marshal/unmarshal requests or replies.
- if the operation exists but no implementation exists, this exception is raised.
- the ORB has run out of memory.
- the caller has insufficient privileges, such as, for example, bad SSL certificate.
- a general platform resource limit exceeded.
- no response available of a deferred synchronous request.
- indicates administrative mismatch; the object adapter is not able to associate an object with the implementation repository.
- the object have been disposed or terminated; clients should remove all copies of the object reference and initiate desired recovery process.
- the ORB was not able to establish a connection to its persistent storage or data contained in the the storage is corrupted.
- a request resulted in, for example, a 'LOCATION_FORWARD' message; if the policies are incompatible this exception is raised.
- raised if a request fail to complete within the given time-limit.
- a transaction is required for the invoked operation but the request contained no transaction context.
- the transaction associated with the request has already been rolled back or will be.
- no transaction context can be supplied since the ORB is unable to contact the Transaction Service.
- the ORB could not determine the current status of an object since it could not be reached. The error may be temporary.
- is thrown if an implementation throws a non-CORBA, or unrecognized, exception.

Account bankAccounts[100];
short matrix[10][20]; // 2D array

se for uma palavra reservada do C++ receberá um

children.value: Mapeamento do módulo padrão do CORBA

props.code: namespace CORBA { ... }
CORBA::ORB_init( ... );

children.value: 32 bit IEEE single precision floating point number
64 bit IEEE double precision floating point number
provê armazenamento para informações da IDL
um programa pode referenciar objetos cuja interface será conhecida em tempo de execução
estas informações podem ser usadas pelo ORB para realizar requisições
pode armazenar outras informações sobre interfaces:
informações que o ORB utiliza para localizar e ativar implementações de um servidor de objetos
máquina onde um servidor pode ser iniciado a partir de uma requisição do cliente
Em vez de chamar um stub específico de uma operação, é possível especificar um objeto, operação e parâmetros para através de uma chamada ou sequência de chamadas
o cliente precisa fornecer os tipos dos parâmetros passados
suporta rede de objetos distribuídos em múltiplos ORBs (heterogêneos)
: (General Inter-ORB Protocol) sintaxe padrão de transferência e conjunto de formato de mensagens
ESIOP: (Environment Specific Inter-ORB Protocol) protocolo especializado
Conectam implementações de objetos ao ORB
Ativam os múltiplos objetos implementados por um servidor
o objeto deve ser registrado com o adaptador
Presente na especificação CORBA até a revisão 2.1
CORBA 2.2 substituiu o BOA pelo POA
ORB com BOA significa que os servidores não são portáveis

O POA interpreta a requisição, empacota a passagem de parâmetros e então
localiza o servant e os tratadores de recuperação erros e de segurança.

Isto habilita portabilidade, independência de fabricantes e extensibilidade
compatível com a especificação da OMG (Object Management Group)

POA também habilita a persistência de objetos bem como dá suporte a ciclo de
vida do serviço
Identificadores de objetos automaticamente gerados ou especificados pelo usuário
Relação: um servant <-> um ou mais objetos CORBA
Aplicação tem total controle sobre o comportamento e sobre a existência dos objetos CORBA
podem usar esqueletos estáticos ou dinâmicos
Valor usado para identificar um objeto no contexto de um POA
Não é um identificador globalmente único!
Pode ser determinado pela aplicação ou gerado pelo POA
O POA coloca esse valor no campo
O Campo Object Id da IOR

props.code:
# Makefile
LDFLAGS+=-lomniORB4 -lomnithread -lomniDynamic4
CXXFLAGS+=-Wall

all: server client

server: DataSK.o CServiceA_i.o Server.o
    $(CXX) $(CXXFLAGS) -o $@ $^ $(LDFLAGS)

client: DataSK.o Client.o CRequestServiceA.o
    $(CXX) $(CXXFLAGS) -o $@ $^ $(LDFLAGS)

clean:
    rm -f *.o
    rm -f server
    rm -f client

children.value:

clean:
    rm -f *.o
    rm -f server
    rm -f client

This is the value of CORBA. This is why we use CORBA. Look at how simple the program looks. The constructor establishes the link with the CORBA server. The subsequent calls to Routine A and B are processed remotely on the CORBA server but called like any other local function call.
Introduction to Distributed Computing using CORBA
O Adaptador de Objetos e Interoperabilidade CORBA
Mapping of OMG IDL Statements to C++
CORBA System and User Defined Exceptions

The OMG CORBA specification defines the following exceptions:
- if a request does not contain a correct context this exception is raised.
- this exception indicates that operations has been invoked operations in the wrong order, which would cause, for example, a dead-lock.
- raised if the target object exists, but that the invoked operation is not supported.
- is thrown if, for example, a parameter is out of range or otherwise considered illegal.
- if illegal type code is passed, for example, encapsulated in an any data type the 'BAD_TYPECODE' exception will be raised.
- raised whenever an object cannot support the required quality of service.
- raised if two ORB's cannot communicate due to different representation of, for example, char and/or wchar.
- raised if an ORB is unable to setup communication or it is lost while an operation is in progress.
- raised if an ORB cannot convert data received to the native representation. See also the 'CODESET_INCOMPATIBLE' exception.
- the ORB failed to free dynamic memory and failed.
- an implementation limit was exceeded in the ORB at run time. A object factory may, for example, limit the number of object clients are allowed to create.
- an internal failure occurred in an ORB, which is unrecognized. You may consider contacting the ORB providers support.
- the ORB was not able to reach the interface repository, or some other failure relating to the interface repository is detected.
- the ORB initialization failed due to, for example, network or configuration error.
- is raised if the request carried an invalid transaction context.
- an invalid flag was passed to an operation, which caused, for example, a connection to be closed.
- this exception indicates that an IDL identifier is incorrect.
- this exception is raised if an objet reference is malformed or a nil reference (see also corba:create_nil_objref/0).
- the invocation cannot be made due to an incompatibility between policy overrides that apply to the particular invocation.
- this exception may be raised by the client- or server-side when either ORB is unable to marshal/unmarshal requests or replies.
- if the operation exists but no implementation exists, this exception is raised.
- the ORB has run out of memory.
- the caller has insufficient privileges, such as, for example, bad SSL certificate.
- a general platform resource limit exceeded.
- no response available of a deferred synchronous request.
- indicates administrative mismatch; the object adapter is not able to associate an object with the implementation repository.
- the object have been disposed or terminated; clients should remove all copies of the object reference and initiate desired recovery process.
- the ORB was not able to establish a connection to its persistent storage or data contained in the the storage is corrupted.
- a request resulted in, for example, a 'LOCATION_FORWARD' message; if the policies are incompatible this exception is raised.
- raised if a request fail to complete within the given time-limit.
- a transaction is required for the invoked operation but the request contained no transaction context.
- the transaction associated with the request has already been rolled back or will be.
- no transaction context can be supplied since the ORB is unable to contact the Transaction Service.
- the ORB could not determine the current status of an object since it could not be reached. The error may be temporary.
- is thrown if an implementation throws a non-CORBA, or unrecognized, exception.
